data.title: Black History Month Activities
data.meta_description: Looking for Black History Month activities in 2024? Here are 5 suggestions that honor the 2024 theme of Black History Month.
data.text:
Looking for Black History Month activities in 2024? Here are 5 suggestions that honor the 2024 theme of Black History Month.

February marks Black History Month, a time to celebrate and honor the achievements and history of Black people in America and beyond. This month is dedicated to acknowledging the impact they have had on our history and culture. This annual observance serves as a means to educate and reflect on the rich heritage and unique experiences of all Black Americans.

2024 Theme

Each year, a theme is explored for this awareness month. In 2024, the theme is African Americans and the Arts, which shines a spotlight on the profound influence of Black Americans on music, visual and performing arts, fashion, film, literature, architecture, culinary, and more. Black artists have not only shaped cultural movements like the Harlem Renaissance and Afrofuturism, but have also used their platforms for empowerment and preservation of history.

Black History Month Activities: Dive into the Arts

Visit Cultural Exhibitions: Museums across the country, like the National Museum of African American History & Culture in Washington D.C., host special exhibitions for Black History Month. This year, focus on galleries showcasing African American art, music, literature, and film to connect with the 2024 theme. Don’t miss virtual tours and online exhibits if you can’t visit in person.

Explore Movies and Books: Dedicate time to watch movies directed by Black filmmakers or featuring Black leads that highlight the stories of the Black and their contributions to the arts. Similarly, reading books by African American authors, like Toni Morrison, Ralph Ellison, or Alice Walker, can offer deeper insights and appreciation.

Support Black Artists and Businesses: Buy art from Black artists or shop at Black-owned Businesses that sell culturally significant products. Many online platforms and local markets feature works by Black artisans, offering a way to support the community directly.

Attend Performances and Workshops: Look for local theaters, community centers, and schools hosting performances by Black musicians, poets, and dancers. Workshops can offer hands-on experiences in Black artistic traditions, from jazz improvisation classes to African dance.

Participate in Library and Online Events: Many libraries host author readings, book clubs, and discussions focused on African American literature and arts. Online platforms and social media channels also offer webinars, lectures, and interactive events that dive into this year’s theme.

Making Black History Month Activities Impactful

As you plan and participate in Black History Month activities, remember that the goal is not only to celebrate but also to understand and honor the contributions and struggles of Black Americans throughout history. Each activity is an opportunity to reflect on the significant impact that Black individuals have had on the arts and how they continue to shape cultural expressions and dialogues today. By focusing on these activities, we can discover how to be an ally to the Black community, not just in February but all year round.

To continue exploring and celebrating diverse cultures and histories beyond Black History Month, explore our Diversity Calendar. This comprehensive resource is designed to help you stay connected with important cultural events, observances, and celebrations throughout the year, creating a deeper understanding and appreciation of our diverse society.

FAQs

How do you engage in Black History Month?

Engaging in Black History Month activities means that you’re learning about a culture different from your own. You will listen to the stories of those in the community. If you’re a DEI leader, you can listen to suggestions for ways to foster a positive work culture for all employees this month too.

How do I host a Black history event?

When you want to host a Black history event, I recommend organizing a keynote speech in your office. You can invite a local historian to come in and speak on Black history or culture in your local community. You can also invite an activist to visit to discuss justice and civil rights movements that you can get involved with.

What are 5 good reasons to celebrate Black History Month?

While there are countless reasons to celebrate Black History Month, here are five great ones. First, learning about Black history (and other communities too) unites us. When we understand each other, we work together better. We also better understand how important all stories are. Black History Month also makes us think deeply about things that may be different from ourselves. It also makes it apparent the importance of every community to thrive together, both in the workplace and beyond.
